docs.lead_paragraph: City limits, property lines and state borders appear clear and inviolable on a map. But things are trickier on the ground, and even more so on the water, where such neatly drawn lines are bypassed by flooding rivers or wandering runoff. Water, particularly in ever-shifting wetlands, meanders between civilization and wilderness, reminding us that both are conduits in a larger circulatory system.
docs.abstract: How images of the Everglades may capture the tipping point between twentieth-century sprawl and twenty-first-century smart growth.
docs.snippet: How images of the Everglades may capture the tipping point between twentieth-century sprawl and twenty-first-century smart growth.

byline.original: By TIM DOODY and CHRISTOPH GIELEN

docs.lead_paragraph: The two largest components of consumers' budgets -- housing and transportation -- fell in 2009, according to the Labor Department's latest Consumers Expenditures survey.

headline.main: Spending on Housing and Transportation Fell in 2009

docs.abstract: Average annual expenditures per consumer unit fell 2.8 percent in 2009. This was the first annual decrease in spending since the Labor Department began publishing this data in 1984.
docs.snippet: Average annual expenditures per consumer unit fell 2.8 percent in 2009. This was the first annual decrease in spending since the Labor Department began publishing this data in 1984.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Meera Oliva last wrote for Motherlode, she shared thoughts about her son, Elan. The boy was born with a cleft lip, and, several days before the surgery, Oliva described how she would miss his imperfect smile, even though she knew the repair was necessary and the timing was right. (Elan's doing wonderfully, she reports, with " just the slightest scar to show where his cleft once was, and we love his new smile just as much as we loved the old one, which we do still miss from time to time.")
docs.abstract: Do you ever stop needing, or wanting, your parents?
docs.snippet: Do you ever stop needing, or wanting, your parents?

docs.lead_paragraph: The global drug market will grow  5 to 7 percent in 2011, to $880 billion, as higher spending in nations like China, Brazil and India makes up for slow growth and patent losses in the United States, according to a forecast released Wednesday by IMS Health, an industry data company.
docs.abstract: Drug sales in China, Brazil and India will help spur industry growth and temper lower growth in the United States.
docs.snippet: Drug sales in China, Brazil and India will help spur industry growth and temper lower growth in the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: The advertising battle is heating up in Colorado's Fourth District, where Representative Betsy Markey is locked in a fierce battle in her bid for a second term.

headline.main: Gloves Off in Colorado House Race

docs.abstract: Representative Betsy Markey, one of the most endangered House Democrats, is trying to hold on to her seat.
docs.snippet: Representative Betsy Markey, one of the most endangered House Democrats, is trying to hold on to her seat.

docs.lead_paragraph: Driven by declines on Wall Street, total personal income earned by residents of metropolitan New York fell last in 2009 for the first time in 40 years - by 4.1 percent - according to the latest data from the government's Bureau of Economic Analysis.

headline.main: Personal Income Drops in New York Region

docs.abstract: Personal income in the region declined in 2009 for the first time in 40 years, by more than double the national rate.
docs.snippet: Personal income in the region declined in 2009 for the first time in 40 years, by more than double the national rate.

docs.lead_paragraph: The administration wants to defuse resistance to the new law by granting waivers to maintain minimal coverage.

headline.seo: U.S. Waivers After Threats of Lost Health Coverage
headline.main: Waivers Aim at Talk of Dropping Health Coverage
headline.print_headline: U.S. Turns to Waivers to Address Talk of Dropping Health Coverage

docs.snippet: The administration wants to defuse resistance to the new law by granting waivers to maintain minimal coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: You won! What a nice run of the House, with a big enough Republican cushion to free the more pumped-up partisans to hold investigations of Obama's birth certificate. Let them throw steak scraps at the base, while the rest of you restore Wall Street, the insurance industry and Karl Rove to their rightful places in power.
docs.abstract: A midterm roundup, before the election even happens.
docs.snippet: A midterm roundup, before the election even happens.

docs.lead_paragraph: Aaron Carroll of Indiana University School of Medicine expands on why he thinks the insurance exchanges to be established by the new health care law will give many McDonald's workers better care for less money:
docs.abstract: A medical professor compares the McDonald's plan to the plans available under the new health law, while a senator asks McDonald's to provide more details about the plan.
docs.snippet: A medical professor compares the McDonald's plan to the plans available under the new health law, while a senator asks McDonald's to provide more details about the plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague, reports:
docs.abstract: Just a few weeks after selling the student lending business at a $500 million loss, Citigroup agreed to sell about $1.6 billion of private-label credit card loans  to GE Capital.
